thread.title: Vince Staples’ “BagBak” Is Swaggering Protest Rap
thread.title_full: Vince Staples’ “BagBak” Is Swaggering Protest Rap

author: Matthew Ismael Ruiz
title: Vince Staples’ “BagBak” Is Swaggering Protest Rap
text:
Via SoundCloud 
Vince Staples is adept at translating the turmoil of growing up poor and brown in urban America into songs that reflect it blow for blow. He can be unsettling, and that’s clearly the point. “BagBak,” his first new track since 2016’s Prima Donna EP , is a sub-3-minute gut-punch that brings his hip-hop braggadocio to the world of protest music. 
Staples’ refined, stream-of-consciousness flow and careful repetition is deployed over a sinister beat, that suggests Detroit techno meets Yeezus . The track’s hollow synth melody, trap hi-hat, and relentless bass come courtesy of Ray Brady, who’s collaborated with Santigold and Kilo Kish . The typically verbose Staples is as concise as ever, bouncing between hot-button issues (mass incarceration, race wars, police profiling, gentrification), building up steam from verse to verse (“Prison system broken/Racial war commotion/Until the president get that/Shit, Vincent won't be votin’”). He’s already spoken eloquently on the issues he raps about; “BagBak” serves more as a direct expression of anger at the forces that oppose his ideals. Coming from Staples, a call for the “one percent,” the government, and the president to “suck a dick” feels like a triumphant call to arms.
